awd_titl_txt: Is the Massalia family of asteroids the source of the L-chondrite meteorites?
awd_abstract_narration:
Asteroids have long been believed to be the primary source of meteorites. In many cases, ?parent? bodies of meteorites have been determined by comparing the way those meteorites and specific asteroids reflect sunlight. However, the parent body of the most common type of meteorites seen to fall, known as ordinary chondrites, has yet to be firmly identified. The team's hypothesis is that a group known as L-chondrites come from the (20) Massalia family of asteroids (An asteroid family is a group of asteroids with orbits more similar than would be expected by chance). The team will use telescopes to break down the light reflected by the Massalia asteroids for comparison with L-chondrites studied in the laboratory. Both undergraduate and graduate students will be included in the research. This project is jointly funded by NSF AST and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

Main belt asteroids are the sole surviving in situ remnants from the formation epoch of the inner Solar System. With few exceptions, meteorites are samples of main belt asteroids. Meteorites thus provide a window into the condition and processes in the late stages of the solar nebula and the earliest evolution of the inner Solar System. Studying meteorites tells us about the geochemistry and petrology of the Solar System, and about its age (from radiometric dating), but nothing about where these processes occurred. If the L-chondrites can be linked to a specific asteroid family, the late nebular and early solar system location of the conditions and processes recorded by the L-chondrites can be constrained. Moreover, the age of that family can be established by the shock ages of the L-chondrites. A firm constraint on the age of a family would allow a more rigorous testing and refining of dynamical models of orbital diffusion in the asteroid belt. Such models are important for: A) constraining the sources of Earth-approaching meteoroids and asteroids, B) for modeling the dynamical evolution of the asteroid population, and C) for estimating the ages of other asteroid families and hence the frequency of large collisions in the belt. The overall goal of the present study is to test the (20) Massalia asteroid family as a potential source of the L-chondrites. This work will be done by comparing spectra of Massalia asteroids for comparison with laboratory spectra of L-chondritic meteorites.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Intrinsic Merit:
The fundamental science question addressed in this research concerns the evolution of asteroid families, and more specifically, Is the Massalia Family the parent body of the L-chondrites?

The main belt asteroids are the sole surviving in situ pristine remnants from the formation epoch of the inner solar system. The meteorites provide a window into the conditions and processes in the late stages of the solar nebula and the earliest evolution of the inner solar system. Meteorite studies provide the what and when of early solar system conditions and processes, but not the where these occurred. For nearly half a century, the scientific community has sought to identify the parent bodies of individual meteorite types in order to place the meteorite data into an early solar system spatial context. Identifying the parent bodies of the ordinary (H-, L- & LL-type) chondrites has been a particular priority. Most proposed identifications of the L-chondrite source have evaporated in the light of subsequent investigations. Identification of the L-chondrite source would establish an early solar system spatial context for the chemical, isotopic and thermal processes recorded in the L-chondrites. Establishing the age of the L-chondrite family would provide a calibration for the dynamical models of asteroid orbital evolution. Improved models would allow determination of more accurate ages for other asteroid families and better estimates of the frequency of disruptive collisions in the asteroid belt, an important factor in the source of Earth-approaching asteroids.

Of the acquired 25 asteroid spectra: we see a variety of meteorite classes represented in our asteroid family sample including H-chondrites, L-chondrites, HEDS, pallasites, and several carbonaceous chondrites.

The Broader Impacts of the research resulted in:

  • An increase in the participation of disabled individuals in the US workforce, as well as a gain in diversity and equal opportunity in society. The NSF grant provided a pathway for the Co-PI (I am disabled) to obtain a tenure track position at a research university resulting in a gain in diversity and equal opportunity in society.
  • Support for minority participation in a STEM related field. I am a disabled female, and females (in general) account for ~29% of the Science and Engineering workforce (NSF National Center for Science and Engineering Statistics, Scientists and Engineers Statistical Data System 2013). Only135 disabled PhDs hold occupations in the field of Physics and Astronomy nationwide (NSF Survey of Earned Doctorates 2014). This is a very small fraction of research scientists, of which I am one. 
  • Mentoring students—two students were taught how to use the NASA IRTF, as assist in writing NASA IRTF Observing Proposals, as well as the data reduction and analysis techniques.
  • The long-term outcomes of the Broader Impacts contribute to improving the development, engagement, and well-being of the STEM workforce.

The Outcomes of this NSF award include:

  • A total of seven presentations were given at the Lunar & Planetary Science Conference in the years 2019-2022.
  • A submission of the results to The Planetary Science Journal (in preparation).
  • The archival of the calibrated spectra to the NASA PDS Small Bodies Node (in preparation).

 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/27/2024
Modified by: Sherry K Fieber-Beyer
